SHEPHERD.</br>Why, Gorbo, as thou cam'st this way,</br>By yonder little hill,</br>Or thro' the vale as thou didst stray,</br>Didst see my Daffadil?</br>She's in a frock of Lincoln green,</br>In green, the maid's delight;</br>No bloom in May so fresh is seen,</br>No lily e'er so white.</br>Than roses richer to behold,</br>That dress up lovers bow'rs;</br>The pansy, and the marigold,</br>Are Phoebus' paramours.
GORBO.</br>Thou well describ'st the Daffadil;</br>It is not full an hour,</br>Since at the spring, by yonder hill,</br>I saw that dainty flower.
SHEPHERD.</br>My flower, Gorbo, didst thou meet?</br>And tidings dost thou bring?</br>Mine's fairer, Gorbo, and more sweet,</br>Than that by yonder spring.

GORBO.</br>I saw a shepherd that does keep</br>Where ouses out the rill,</br>A-making, as he fed his sheep,</br>A wreath all Daffadil.</br>And down the glade as I did pass,</br>Descending from the hill,</br>I met a dainty smiling lass,</br>They call her Daffadil.</br>The shepherds all were passing by,</br>Just then, I wist, did stop and cry,</br>There goes sweet Daffadil.
SHEPHERD.</br>Ay, Gorbo, now with mirth and joy</br>My heart thou dost fulfil;</br>And all the shepherds they did cry,</br>There goes sweet Daffadil.</br>
